fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G : \mathcal { D } \to \mathcal { C } be a functor with a left adjoint F. G is monadic iff G creates coequalizers whose image under G is split.
For necessity, using , we only need to verify that a monad M preserves the relevant coequalizers, which is true since they are absolute.

For sufficiency, we observe the proof of . Notice that the coequalizers involved are of the form F \alpha , \epsilon : FGFA \rightrightarrows FA. The images of these under G are indeed split by \eta : GFA \to GFGFA and \eta : A \to GFA. Therefore we just have to show G reflects isomorphisms. Given an isomorphism Gf : GA \cong GB, we have a split coequalizer GA \rightrightarrows GB \to GA where the two maps on the left are Gf, and the map on the right is its inverse. This creates a map g : B \to A which is the coequalizer of f with itself. So this map must be an isomorphism. We then consider the coequalizer GB \rightrightarrows GA \to GB, where the two maps on the left are Gg and the map on the right is Gf. Since G reflects this limit, f must also be an isomorphism.

Given a coequalizer diagram X \rightrightarrows Y \to Z where \partial _0, \partial _1 : X \to Y are the two parallel arrows and the coequalizing arrow is e : Y \to Z, it is absolute, if and only if the following conditions hold.

fr:ul.fr:li: e is split epimorphic, i.e. there is an arrow r such that e \circ r = \textrm {id} _Z.

There is a list of n endomorphisms on Y starting with r \circ e and ending with \textrm {id} _Y, such that for each pair of adjacent morphisms, there is an arrow s such that \partial _0 \circ s and \partial _1 \circ s are equal to the two morphisms (in some order).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that for n = 0 this is the trivial coequalizer where \partial _0 = \partial _1 and e is an isomorphism. For n = 1 this results in the split coequalizer.

By the definition of an absolute (co)limit, the coequalizer is preserved by every functor. Consider the functor \hom (Z, -). We have \hom (Z, e) is a coequalizer map, and hence epimorphic. This means e itself is split epimorphic since \textrm {id} _Z is in the image, i.e. there is a morphism r : Z \to Y with e \circ r = \textrm {id} _Z.

Next, we consider the functor \hom (Y, -). Since this gives a coequalizer of sets, the quotient \hom (Y, Y) \xrightarrow {e \circ -} \hom (Y, Z) is given by the equivalence relation generated by \partial _0 \circ f = \partial _1 \circ f for every f : Y \to X. There is a pair of elements mapped to the same element under e \circ - in this situation: one of them is obviously \textrm {id} _Y, and the other is r \circ e, since e \circ \textrm {id} _Y = e = e \circ r \circ e. Hence we get the chain of morphisms related in the way stated in the theorem.

Finally, we observe that these are enough to guarantee the given diagram is a coequalizer —— the diagram is a coequalizer simply by virtue of the shape of the diagram. Since any functor preserves the composition relation of morphisms, they must also give coequalizers, and therefore the coequalizer is absolute.
